ETYMOLOGY: From Medieval Latin embryō, from Ancient Greek ἔμβρυον (émbruon, 'young animal, embryo'), from ἐν (en, 'in') + βρύω (brúō, 'I swell, I grow').

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things, or to name a particular one of these.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: An unborn or unhatched offspring in the process of development, especially a human offspring during the period from approximately the second to the eighth week after fertilization (after which it is usually termed a fetus).
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 未出生或未孵化的正在发育的后代，特别是指受精后约第二到第八周的人类后代（此后通常称为胎儿）。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The embryo develops rapidly during the first few weeks of pregnancy.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 胚胎在怀孕的最初几周内迅速发育。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things, or to name a particular one of these.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Something in an early stage of development, especially one which shows promise or potential.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 处于早期发展阶段的事物，尤指那些有希望或潜力的事物。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The initial proposal was just an embryo of the grand project it would eventually become.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 最初的提案只是这个宏大项目的一个雏形。

REGISTER: Formal to scientific for the biological sense; general for the figurative sense.
